sub_topics.title: Forms of Written Literature

instructional_blocks.hook: What do you understand by literature?
teacher_steps: Find out from the learners the meaning of literature
Divide the class into small groups and each group to be tasked to discuss the meaning and features of written literature provided to them on pieces of paper
Carry out a plenary session to share the different definitions and features of written literature discussed
Consolidate the learners' presentations by highlighting key points about written literature
learner_steps: Discussing the meaning of literature in groups
Presenting group findings in plenary session
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Written literature is defined as any form of literary work that is recorded in written form rather than being passed down orally. It includes texts that are created for various purposes, such as storytelling, entertainment, education, or preserving history. Written literature employs specific diction, figurative language and syntax to convey themes and emotions.

instructional_blocks.hook: What are the different forms in which literature can be written?
teacher_steps: Put learners in small groups and ask them to discuss forms of written literature
Each group to look at one form of written literature â€“ prose, poetry or drama
Ask group representatives to present their group's findings
Conduct a plenary session to discuss what has been presented
Consolidate the learners' presentations by explaining the various forms of written literature
learner_steps: Discussing forms of written literature in groups
Focusing on one form (prose, poetry, or drama)
instructional_blocks.short_notes: There are several forms of written literature: 1) Prose - written in continuous sentences and paragraphs, divided into fiction and non-fiction. 2) Drama - meant to be performed in front of an audience, consisting of dialogues and actions. 3) Poetry - uses rhythmic and figurative language to express emotions and ideas, written in lines and stanzas.

sub_topics.short_notes: Written literature is any form of literary work that is recorded in written form rather than being passed down orally. It differs from oral literature in that it is permanent and unchanged, while oral literature relies on memory and can vary with retellings. The main forms of written literature are prose, drama, and poetry, each with unique characteristics and purposes.

questions: Put the learners in pairs and ask them to explore various definitions of written literature and distinguish written literature from oral literature
Through a written exercise, ask learners to discuss the various forms of written literature

sub_topics.title: Prose

instructional_blocks.hook: What makes a piece of writing prose? Can you identify prose in the materials around you?
teacher_steps: Put learners in groups and distribute newspapers and biographies to different groups
Task each group to take note of whether the materials are written in continuous sentences
Task groups to note whether the passages talk about real people
Carry out a plenary session where different salient features will be written on the board
Consolidate the learners' presentation by highlighting key points about prose
learner_steps: Noting characteristics of the writing style
Identifying whether content is about real people
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Prose writing is a form of continuous writing in the form of sentences and paragraphs. Prose can either be fiction or non-fiction. Fiction is based on the author's imagination while non-fiction focuses on real events, people, places and shows a specific period of time. Examples of fiction include novels, short stories and novellas. Examples of non-fiction include newspapers, biographies, true adventure stories, essays and autobiographies.

instructional_blocks.hook: How do authors organize fictional stories to make them engaging?
teacher_steps: Display a flip chart with a short story and initiate a discussion based on its structure and elements
Generate questions that will enlist responses about fiction elements
Consolidate learners' responses about plot, setting, and character
learner_steps: Identifying exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Fiction is based on the writer's imagination. Fiction has key elements: Plot (sequence of events centered on conflict with exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution), Setting (time and place), and Character (major characters are at the center of the story, minor characters play smaller roles).

instructional_blocks.hook: What makes a story interesting and keeps readers engaged?
teacher_steps: Put learners in groups and assign each group to discuss a short story and Plot as one of its elements
Provide excerpts of short stories for consideration
Ask group representatives to present the findings
Conduct a plenary session
Consolidate by highlighting plot types and structure
learner_steps: Discussing plot in assigned short stories
Identifying stages of plot: exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution
Distinguishing between simple and complex plots
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Plot is the sequence of events on which the story is centered. A simple plot follows the traditional stages from beginning to end. A complex plot does not follow traditional stages and might start from the middle or end.

instructional_blocks.hook: Who are the people in the story and what roles do they play?
teacher_steps: Ask learners to explain what a character is in a story
Put learners in groups to discuss Character as an element of a short story
Provide excerpts of short stories for consideration
Ask group representatives to present findings
Conduct a plenary session
Consolidate by highlighting types of characters
learner_steps: Identifying different types of characters in short stories
Identifying round, flat/static, and dynamic characters
instructional_blocks.short_notes: A Character is a participant in the action of a story. Characters can be people, animals, objects or concepts. Types include: Protagonist (main character), Antagonist (opposes the protagonist), Round character (well-developed with good and bad traits), Flat/Static character (unchanging with limited traits), and Dynamic character (undergoes important personality change).

instructional_blocks.hook: What message or lesson is the author trying to convey?
teacher_steps: Introduce the concept of theme and how themes can be deduced in a short story
Use the short story 'The Dried-Up River' as an example
Put learners in groups to identify and discuss themes in provided short stories
Ask group representatives to present findings
Conduct a plenary session
Consolidate by highlighting common themes
learner_steps: Discussing how themes are deduced through character behavior
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Theme is the central or main idea in a short story. It is often the reason the author writes the story. The theme can be deduced through character behavior. Many stories are written to make important observations about society. A story can have more than one theme. Common themes include: Good vs Evil, Injustice, Love, Sin, Hate, Death, Growth, Pride, Climate Change.

instructional_blocks.hook: What problem or struggle drives the story forward?
teacher_steps: Introduce the concept of conflict
Refer to 'The Dried-Up River' story for examples
Put learners in groups to discuss conflict as an element
Provide short story excerpts for analysis
Ask group representatives to present findings
Conduct plenary session
Consolidate by highlighting types of conflict
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Conflict is the problem or struggle that the character encounters which drives the plot forward and creates tension. Types include: Internal (struggle within oneself), External (struggle with outside force), Character vs Character, Character vs Nature, and Character vs Society.

instructional_blocks.hook: When and where does the story take place?
teacher_steps: Based on 'The Dried-Up River', ask learners to identify time and place
Provide short stories for learners to identify setting in groups
Ask group representatives to present findings
Conduct a plenary session
Consolidate key points about setting
learner_steps: Identifying time when the story takes place
Identifying place where the story happens
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Setting is the time and place: Place refers to where the story takes place, Time refers to when the story takes place. Some stories have more than one setting.

instructional_blocks.hook: Who is telling the story and from what perspective?
teacher_steps: Based on 'The Dried-Up River', ask learners to identify the point of view
Provide short stories for learners to identify point of view in groups
Ask group representatives to present findings
Conduct a plenary session
Consolidate by explaining types of point of view
learner_steps: Distinguishing first person (I, me, we) narration
Recognizing third person (names, him, her) narration
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Point of view is the perspective or angle from which the story is told. Types: First Person (I, me, we - character is narrator), Second Person (you, your, yours - narrator talks to reader, not commonly used), Third Person (names of people, him, her - narrator is outside the story).

instructional_blocks.hook: How do you create an engaging short story?
teacher_steps: Lead a discussion on the characteristics of a short story
Divide the class into groups and task each group to plan the stages of plot for a given short story
Let each group representative present their plan to the class
Conduct a class discussion of what each group presented
Consolidate by highlighting characteristics and composition process
learner_steps: Developing exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution
Identifying theme and point of view
Presenting story plans to the class
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Short stories are: Short and can be read in one sitting, Concise with relevant information, Captivating, Built around one character, place and idea. Composition involves planning stages of plot including all elements: exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution, along with characters, conflict, theme, and point of view.

sub_topics.short_notes: Prose is continuous writing in sentences and paragraphs, either fiction (based on imagination) or non-fiction (based on real events). Key elements of prose fiction include: Plot (sequence of events with exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution), Character (protagonist, antagonist, round, flat, dynamic), Theme (central idea), Conflict (internal/external struggle), Setting (time and place), Point of View (perspective of narration). Short stories are brief fictional narratives centered on one idea with all these elements working together.

questions: Pair the learners and let them interview one another and write each other's biographies
Avail a short story and ask: Where is the story set? Who is telling the story? How many characters are in the story? Identify the major and minor characters
Administer an exercise for learners to identify the elements of Plot in a short story
Administer an exercise for learners to identify the types of characters in short stories provided
Administer an exercise for learners to deduce themes in a short story
Administer an exercise for learners to identify and explain the conflict(s) in a short story
Administer an exercise on setting as a concept of a short story
Administer an exercise to learners to identify point of view in short stories
